citations.narrative:
Within the past 8 months there have been numerous photographs posted on a social media platform showing the general
viewing public with different species of non-human primates as well as a coati sitting on top of the head, on the shoulders,
being “kissed”, and being cuddled on the neck. The close proximity of the animals to persons’ face, neck and head could
cause physical harm to the viewing public and/or animals as well as could lead to the transmission of communicable
diseases.
During public exhibition, animals must be handled in such a manner so there is minimal risk of harm to the animals and to
the public with sufficient distance and/or barriers to assure the safety of the animals and the public.
Correct by 22 August 2023.

Within the past 8 months there have been numerous photographs posted on a social media platform showing young non-
human primates on the publics’ head, shoulder, chest and lap without any restraint device nor with an attendant in view.
According to the licensee, these animals are placed on the person’s body by an employee and then that employee steps
a few paces away during the contact. Non-human primates used for physical contact with the public without direct control
could cause harm or injury to these non-human primates.
Only trained non-human primates may be permitted physical contact with the public but only if the primates are under the
direct control and supervision of an experienced handler or trainer at all times during the contact. Examples of training
and direct control include primates responding appropriately to verbal commands of the handler/trainer and/or some type
of physical attachment (e.g. leash, tether) affixed to a collar or harness on the primate and held firmly by the
handler/trainer.
Correct by 15 Oct. 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
